title: Monday, 19th February, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:10 am
BE11:11am

Yes, yes, I know. Very late. Sorry. Sometimes the day job gets in the way.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
Soundbuy Morning
BE11:11am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the whatever.

Dogpowder hi
Blank canvas All very Kafkaesque
Cavendish Square Afternoon all
Otter Hello friends.
DerivedCategory Morning
Miss Piggy oh hello, honky tonks
BE11:12am

Here's something interesting that dropped when we should have been online.

Swedish Chef It is early evening in Thailand and I am contemplating the purchase of Durex and Dettol. Can BE offer guidance?

Valueact -- they of Rolls Royce among others -- turning up with 5.4% of Merlin.

Nately Ahoy

Merlin's been theorised to be a breakup target for quite a while .....

rwl hi
11:13 am
BE11:13am

And is bouncing around at IPO level.

GBKrona Hola
BE11:14am

The idea was always to split out the theme parks and the Legoland franchise, both of which are asset backed.

LJ morning all
BE11:14am

And leave Midway, the portfolio of smaller stuff like Sea Life and The Shrek Experience

MnM Morning, anything to add Fidessa spike last few days
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Where LFL has been flatlining for some time, because if you go to one Shrek Experience you probably don't need to go to another.

BE11:16am

Who did this argument last time around? Numis, I think?

BE11:16am

Here they are last week.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Stock's derating more than reflects estimate risk giving attractive MT
opportunity: MERL's share price has underperformed by 10% since its wk40 update.
It is now trading back at its IPO price from 2013, notwithstanding 20% EPS growth over
that period and an expected CAGR of 9% over the next 3y. We view the 2018E P/E of
15.2x and EV/EBITDA 9.0x as attractive vs peers and relative to EPS growth. Sales
momentum may remain negative for several more quarters which could weigh on ST
performance. However, we expect GARP investors to start to take more interest which
could underpin material upside on a 12m view. The ROCE is 8.5% whereas EV/IC of
1.5x suggests the share price attaches low probability to recovery in returns in future
(see figure 7). We see 40% upside to our DCF-based target price.

BE11:17am

Actually, the breakup note was some time before. One second ......

wayneJ @BE - the Lego family own a stake which will act as a block
estrangedcapitalist Ello chaps
estrangedcapitalist Greetings from Rome
Swedish Chef @wayne a Lego block then...
wayneJ (Kirkbi Invest = Lego family firm - 29.72%).
BE11:18am

(@wayneJ: did you intend that as a pun? Because it's a very good one.)

A. M. Morning all. The BrankoM link was a fun read.
Forester As a holder, I have noticed quite a lot of buying over the last few days...something leaky?
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Finally! Found it!

wayneJ Also their crown jewel = Alton Towers - where there was a sale and leaseback IIRC (perhaps others can correct). And the business has been weak due to the accident at Alton Towers + Terrorism in London - neither are issues that I suspect ValueAct has much input on.
wayneJ @BE - accidental!
BE11:20am

The delivery of strategic synergies is an important part of the six growth drivers which
form Merlin’s business model. Our perception is that investors have yet to be totally
convinced of the value of the overall Merlin group structure and perceive a varying level
of attractiveness in terms of growth potential and earnings visibility from the three
divisions preferring the growth prospects of Legoland to MW and RTP. The latter is a
low ROCE business with pronounced seasonality and wide peak-trough in earnings
terms. In contrast Legoland has grown EBITDA at a CAGR of 14.5% since IPO. While
there are attractive accommodation opportunities across the group, these are also
skewed towards Legoland parks (147 rooms/million visitors vs 166 at RTP).
The other attraction for a break up would relate to real estate. Four parks are operated
on long term leases and owned by Secure Income REIT (Alton Towers, Thorpe Park,
Warwick Castle, Heidepark). Of the remaining RTP sites, Gardaland and Chessington
are owned on a freehold basis meaning Merlin retains the underlying real estate value.
Similarly, while more recent LLPs (Japan and Korea) have been developed on a
leasehold basis legacy assets such as Windsor, Billund, Florida, California and
Deutschland are owned outright. The intrinsic value in such real estate is not captured
by the group’s current EV/EBITDA in our opinion.

Forester @wayne as with other scandi corporates with family foundations, I suspect the foundations ability to block is even higher than the 29% stakes they hold
wayneJ The business is going through an investment phase - building lots of hotel rooms.
BE11:21am

And breakup value ......

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Forester High barriers to entry, strong worldwide brand, plenty of growing markets to expand into - its a long term tuck away and hold for me at recent prices even if debt is a bit on the high side.
wayneJ I love the leaseback model - what better way for private equity MBAs to extract value, and move on - leaving the business to implode a few years later because all the leases were on upward only rent reviews.....no private equity guy seems to ever realise that increasing debts increase risk. (end of rant)
BE11:23am

Speak to Numis for the rest. Tim Barrett's leisure team over there is excellent.

undefined
wayneJ Of course there is nothing to stop analysts or the management revaluing the property each year and putting it into the accounts as a footnote; or taking a mortgage directly on the property rather than via the agency of a property co.
11:23 am
BE11:24am

Okay, what else do we have? Fidessa mentioned.

Blue horseshoe... Any thoughts Innogy re RWE stake?
Soundbuy Merlin - reckon they could pull something out of the hat........
BE11:24am

Results are good, as in better than expected, but it's the margin guidance that's got people excited.

Fidessa Group PLC (FDSA:LSE): Last: 2,775, up 170 (+6.53%), High: 2,895, Low: 2,745, Volume: 57.19k
11:24 am
BE11:25am

The upshot is that Fidessa will stop chucking money at derivatives and Mifid II compliance within the next year or so .....

wayneJ Merlin will argue that by having a number of smaller units in close proximity eg in London they can sell packages - the issue then is how are profits / revenues attributed to the different units.
A. M. @WayneJ - true. a different approach to taking out a loan to pay dividends to the new owners..
BE11:25am

.... and unless it can find something else to invest that money on, margins will go rather better.

Mouselet Good morning all
BE11:26am

Jefferies turns buyer.

red @wayneJits a fave in care home sector and whats causing a huge problem in what in other circumstances a highly profitable business. but unfortunately few businesses can support the ever growing appetite of private equity
11:26 am
BE11:26am

FY17 results signal the end of the investment phase in building out the derivatives business as well as getting its cash equities platform MiFID II ready. While Fidessa continues to target expansion into new markets, the limited visibility on such opportunities implies that we now expect EBIT margin to expand significantly, driving 12-13% EPS upgrades for FY19E-22E. With the emergence of clarity on future margin evolution, we upgrade to Buy and raise PT to £31.

BE11:27am

In our previous research, we cited clarity on future margin evolution as one of the factors that would help us get off the fence. In its FY17 results, Fidessa notes that from FY19E, it will have greater investment capacity that can either be re-invested to develop new opportunities or deliver an increase in margin.

wayneJ @AM - I once looked at nursing / care homes where a certain operator did massive sale and leasebacks with upward only CPI linked rent escalators in order to maximise the value of the homes......funnily enough when local councils started putting in caps on how much they spent per bed....and regulations led to increased staff and plant / equipment costs.....
Stateless I feel like "Invest" should have been in inverted brackets there @BE, also apparently regulation is stealth taxation :P
Mouselet ... considers a stock-market rule such that companies IPOing out of private equity is only permitted if they have zero debt
BE11:28am

Given the limited visibility on new markets, we believe margin expansion is more likely and hence increase our FY19E EBIT margin to 16.2% (from 14.3%).

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Furthermore, if the status quo on new markets remains unchanged, we believe there is scope for continued significant margin expansion albeit for now we assume only a modest EBIT margin increase (c.25bps pa) in FY20E and beyond. It is worth pointing out that our unchanged FY17 22E revenue CAGR at constant FX of c. 4% assumes limited benefits from new markets.

Mouselet the care-home stuff is a complete disaster, especially with Brexit on top meaning that Polish nurses are no longer so delighted by the British minimum wage
A. M. @WayneJ - by which time, the bright spark who had thought up that scheme was long gone?
estrangedcapitalist Ello chaps
wayneJ Would be interesting to see the read across to Accesso - would not be the first time a private equity player tries renegotiating contracts downward....
Mouselet I suppose when I have my Lenin hat on I would also suggest forbidding the rental or use for business purposes of mortgaged property
A. M. @Mouselet: perhaps, along the lines of that FTAV piece from last week, there should be an offer of a residency/citizenship in exchange for care-sector servitude..
BE11:29am

And Barclays ......

Mouselet but how is British residency and citizenship particularly a prize for a Polish nurse?
wayneJ @AM - I have probably said too much but this particular business managed to go into 'administration' (or forced change of ownership) on more than one occasion in the last couple of decades
BE11:30am

Just for the sake of a counterpoint.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Consensus (Bloomberg) is currently forecasting £353.0m in FY18 revenues, implying a marginal reported decline y/y. The company is once again guiding to organic growth for the coming year in line with the reported year. However, this will be offset by an FX headwind (we estimate at least 5%), and therefore consensus looks in line with this. The company is also guiding to a “small increase in PBT margin” this year, but this is on a reported basis as the absence of the move and lease costs are partially offset by the FX impact. This suggests a reduction in margin on an adjusted basis. The £50.6m PBT that consensus is currently looking for we think is on a reported basis, and with an implied margin of 14.3% (consistent with guidance for a slight increase from the 14.1% reported this year). Finally, the tax rate is guided to 23%, some 400bp below our current modelling, and this is likely to mean modest increases in EPS overall, in our view.

BE11:30am

Fidessa’s revenue model is attractive and the business clearly has strategic value; however, its earnings growth is among the lowest in the sector and, without valuation multiple upside, we continue to rate the shares Underweight. We retain our price target of £19.90 at 17x cash adjusted FY19E PE.

A. M. @Mouselet -- there is that. Perhaps they would have to go further afield with that kind of offer.
undefined
red @Mouseletno so much these days i dont think. plenty of opportunities back home or next door in Germany if there is still the need.
wayneJ Incidentally IIRC another issue for Merlin is that it is subject to the success or otherwise of Lego movies - which again is out the control of private equity. I can't remember but I suspect the Lego name is also licensed to Merlin so there is likely to be a change of control clause.....
Mouselet And do we really want to denude Ghana of nurses?
red care business is very much misunderstood. most private owners are driving lambos

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 6,208, down 360 (-5.48%), High: 6,448, Low: 6,133, Volume: 1.17m
kim @Mouselet There's also an argument for limiting the ability of any business (or individual) to grant a mortgage over assets to obtain finance. It makes it too easy to acquire assets of highly speculative value.

wayneJ I actually think mortgages for business are a very good idea - mean that debt is ON the balance sheet rather than OFF the balance sheet with leasebacks,
11:33 am

This time around we have a caution on margins due mostly to Mead Johnson integration costs and such.

Mouselet I do not understand why off-balance-sheet doesn't completely defeat the purposes both of balance sheets and of publicly-listed companies
Pharma @Mouselet, where would you like your PhD to be from? I know a place (and it's not so easy to find out they are fake - look at all the German politicians who either had no doctorate, or simply plagiarised it)
BE11:35am

Here's RBC.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Q4 like-for-like sales growth of 2.0% was in line with the company compiled consensus of 2.1%. Likewise EBIT of £3,122m (consensus £3,145m) and EPS of
316.9 pence (consensus 318.9). Management has acknowledged the benefit of a strong start to the flu season in Q4’s results, which in our view had been
widely anticipated. Mead Johnson delivered +3% organic sales growth in Q4, up from +1% in Q3, which we think was a good performance. Synergy
expectations for Mead Johnson have been increased to $300m from $250m.
Like-for-like sales growth in Q4 was ‘volume led’. We are concerned at the lack of value growth which, in our view, has been a crucial element of RB’s historic
success. We wonder to what extent this, in addition to the formation of RB 2.0 – the separate Health and Hygiene/Home business units – plays a part in
management’s expectation of ‘some specific factors impacting margin’ for 2018. Consensus is for margins to decline by 10 basis points; RBC’s forecast is for
50 basis points of margin decline in 2018, which we feel is more realistic. Like-for-like sales growth guidance of 2-3% is in line with consensus forecast of 2.8%.
Finally, there is (unsurprisingly, in our opinion) no reference to RB’s interest, or lack thereof, in acquiring Pfizer’s Consumer Health business.

Pharma (should probably amend that to "your second PhD")
red they get paid between 500 to a grand per week per bed, yet still cant make money, yet private owners are able to and change lambos every year.
BE11:35am

We are not convinced the acquisition of Mead Johnson works strategically, operationally or financially, and if it does it comes with a higher level of risk than
anything RB has acquired before given the size of the transaction. We expect a continuation of the recent slowdown in RB's growth rate given the company's
exposure to uninspiring categories as well as innovation and pricing fatigue. Underperform.

BE11:36am

Where are we on the Pfizer auction? Just Reckitt and GSK left, last reported, right?

FATDAZ @LJthat seems excessive given lacklustre stock performance
A. M. @red: reminds me of 'waiting for god', but the reality is grimmer
kim I would include finance leases in the restrictions. They are used to realise an immediate distributable profit (through a "third party" sale) with little economic benefit in present value terms.
wayneJ @red - I think the issue is that a listed / large business has substantial management overheads. The successful ones are those where the managements actually have experience and understanding of the business.
red @A. M.no point in wrapping it up in cotton wool, folks go their to die.
11:37 am
BE11:38am

The split of Hygiene and Home has led most people to assume that Hygiene grows and Home is, at some point in the future, sold off. But landing Pfizer CH seems to be a big part of that plan and Reckitt's problems with Mead aren't too encouraging there.

BE11:38am

Citi incoming .........

LJ @FATDAZ- very much so considering the shares are 23% off their year high of 8108
FATDAZ @ red but they dont go quickly or quietly enough for Dignity's liking as we saw here a few weeks ago
wayneJ Re leases etc - it is the inverse of the ignoring assets on the balance sheet. So to me an analyst looking at eg Merlin should treat the leases as debt but should also include the uplift in land prices for the wholly owned sites. And I know as a property rich company it will have a lower ROE - but the correct ROE will be LOWER if the debt is properly included.
red @wayneJthe more beds you have the more money you make wayne. but its milked by large investment funds, purposely, as they know the government would need to intervene if 20 thousand beds suddenly disappeared.
BE11:39am

This set of results may not reassure yet, and confirms some of the pressure the group is facing as several of its categories see changing economics and as management deals with the aftermath of 2016-17 one-offs. However, beyond a foreseeable tough H1, we see optionality increasing throughout the year, for a stock still at a discount to peers.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

What on earth does "we see optionality increasing throughout the year" actually mean? Selling stuff and buying stuff, I guess.

undefined
Tom Dalgleish @Red, I never believe doomsday stuff
GBKrona @BE re"Pfizer - just GSK now, who will not buy it because of the divi impact?Hope Pfizer open to creative options with GSK - e.g. standalone consumer JV
BE11:40am

Just realised we haven't mentioned the FTSE. It's flat. There. Done.

Forester @red family has lots of experience in care sector. Problem is that homes have massive increases in costs - energy, regulation, food etc etc but LA's have capped fees year on year. All the "good" little private homes have no chance and only ones left are the giant "warehouse 2 homes. If you went to a hotel and asked for 7 days full board and to be taken to the toilet 10 times a day etc etc do you think £500 would cover it? Alas with an aging population, residents in homes used to be 70-85, now they are 85-100 and are more frail etc.
red even 20 bed homes clear 15 to 20 grand a month. economies of scale mean larger ones will clear more.
wayneJ I first looked at nursing homes in about 1989 or so - and foolishly decided to avoid - based on the premise that the main source of revenue is LA that at some point will increase at less than CPI; and main cost is debt + staff (latter will go up at > CPI)
FATDAZ @ LJ not much obvious sign of alignment between shareholders and CEO is there not really one for additional regulation or pay caps but do think examples like this just give ammo to those who do back those ideas.
LJ @FATDAZ I think you would be best of speaking with holders of WPP...
Pharma @Forester honest question, are today's 85-100 year olds more frail than 70-85 year olds in the 70s and 80s. My memories of grandparents suggests not.
red your largest costs are staff and you can spread that around the more beds you have.
wayneJ @red - depends on how you acquire the site - and what cost you allocate vs capital
A. M. @red: how so? more beds --> more staff.
11:43 am
BE11:43am

(@GBKrona: I've heard nothing to suggest GSK's out of the running, and don't think a divi cut would be nailed on -- though clearly that depends on price. https://www.ft.com...-9650-9c0ad2d7c5b5 )

Soundbuy Stick two in a bed surely?
chopper bear any grey in run upto centricas results ? see sunday times did a brief bit over weekend

Anyway. What else? AA? There's AA. What about AA?

Tom Dalgleish Seems a natural roll up for Dignity

wayneJ The John Hempton article on GE and buybacks was interesting - wondering if the same might apply to some UK cos.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Berenberg talking divi. Or rather, lack of divi.

LJ @FATDAZ- although only up 38% since 2013 when the FTSE has moved significantly higher
VV75 Anything on friday's news that Acacia's owner is talking to the Chinese for a (partial) sale?
Kiwi-juice the AA - curse of PE ownership. I wonder how much capex is needed to take it back to the right invested level
BE11:46am

Because when you have more than £2bn of net debt and net profit in the £130m sort of area, you probably shouldn't be paying a divi. This doesn't look like news but apparently it is.

BE11:46am

Here's the gist.

FATDAZ @LJ surfing QE not really Martin Sorrells job but take your point
11:46 am
BE11:46am

We downgraded The AA to Hold in October last year, with a thesis that consensus expectations for the company were too high, and that additional investments announced by the new CEO were likely to increase costs and worsen the company’s cash generation. Revisiting the investment case following the recent trading update, we now believe the short-term risks to be greater than previously assumed, and are of the view that the company’s dividend will need to be cut; we also think that the strategy update planned for 21 February is likely to significantly increase investment into the business, further pushing the possible deleveraging story into the outer years. Given these factors, we downgrade to Sell and reduce our price target to 100p.

red @wayneJ20 years ago you could build a 30 bedder for less than a million. these days you need 3 or 4. and the bar now is much higher will checks and regs.
FATDAZ @BE that message had nt reached Carillion directors had it
Pharma @Forester, fair enough. I just seem to remember old age starting earlier. It is always the last 2-3 years that are most expensive.(if people are getting type II diabetes in their teens, then that may not be true in 10-20 years time)
BE11:47am

With new CEO Simon Breakwell’s first strategy update to the market to come on 21 February, we expect significant further investments to be announced, particularly in the insurance underwriting business, IT systems and higher patrol levels. This (again) pushes the company’s deleveraging story further into the future. On current forecasts, we forecast the AA’s leverage at 6.5x 2020E net debt/EBITDA, or 7.5x including the company’s £395m pension deficit.

BE11:48am

And here's the grit.

wayneJ @red - yep - and that is the issue. The people who really profited are those who bought freeholds 30 yrs ago (+/- mortgage) and hence are not repricing of today's replacement cost.
11:48 am
BE11:48am

The company’s dividend gating ratio states that the maximum dividend payout is equal to the difference between 5.5x maintenance EBITDA and the total Class A net debt position. With our forecast Class A net debt position of £2,125m, and £385m of 2019E EBITDA, this would imply a permitted investor payout of -£5m, meaning that no further payout would be possible.

December69 The only way forward is their insurance, lets face it, the marginality on towing your vehicle to a garage is in the all time crapper.
December69 The dividend is smoked!
red @Pharmaquite, i definitely wouldnt extrapolate increasing avg ages any further. i suspect given poor diet and general health, that it will be seen to go the other way over next decade
Forester @wayne really? Yy mother spent 30 years as a care home manager & owner - hate to break it to her but she would have been better off now if she had just sat on the land for 30 years, without the gut busting work!
BE11:49am

You'll remember also that AA's having to cope with the FCA clamping down on renewal rate hikes.

FATDAZ re the AA will come back to my assertion that they should merge with saga
December69 @Forester, I suspect, if she was an owner manager, something else drove her, something I suspect that is commendable more so than the appreciation of land
wayneJ @Forester - my analysis - but if eg the home was revalued to today's prices and she had a capital charge according to that the economics would be different. Obviously an owner would also benefit from the goodwill that has been created - but that is cyclical
BE11:51am

Meaning the new chap has a lot on his plate in terms of trying to figure out what AA does, and what it should be doing.

red @ Foresterdepends on how you run it and how much time off you want if its a small home. a larger one means you can run with managers. you have to think big otherwise you have no room to grow. anythiung less than 20 beds means you probably need to be there yourself.
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Wednesday could be interesting.

Soundbuy AA - to stop automatic renewal you have to phone IIRC, not possible through online account........we chop and change most years
undefined

December69 @FatDaz, the AA has to merge with Sage, just so as the AA work force retires they have a repeat income. ;-)
Soundbuy Esure's looking for a new home.............
December69 @Forester, I was meaning she actually cared...but yes the capital allocation issue could also be true.
FATDAZ @DEC69 saw some other potential synergies buy will; add that to the list :)
wayneJ @red - my data is years old but even in the early '90s I reckoned you needed 30+ beds to have any economy of scale. The other issue with modelling a care /nursing home (or hospital) is the 'bad debt' issue - eg very hard to eject a resident of 5 yrs+ if they run out of money
BE11:53am

Hm ...... what else?

red @wayneJgoodwill goes out window when selling as just property. if it can be still run as a home by someone else then yes. but needs to be large enough and up to standard.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Blue horseshoe... XL?

Forester @December yes she cared, still visits her old ladies. However, the last few years were terrible {I know as I was doing the finances etc]. Frankly we are going down the US model now for better or for worse.
December69 @BE the story could get even more interesting. If the Tanzania Government override and take the lot (actually for a premium).

Idea here is a potential purchase at the asset level for some or all the Tanzanian operations to create a 50-50 JV.

FATDAZ @Pseudo was thinking perhaps they could do something in EV fleet management / charging stations etc
11:54 am
BE11:55am

And not, to be clear, a bid for Acacia itself.

BE11:55am

Quick comment from RBC.

December69 Wonder what the inventory will be priced at @BE...
BE11:55am

ur expectations would be that any transaction would need to be predicated on a detailed final agreement on the recently agreed framework between Barrick
and Tanzania, which would be a positive for the equity independently. Should a cash deal be struck, in theory Acacia could dividend out the cash to its
shareholders, which would allow for at least an in-part monetization of Acacia, which has previously been named non-core.
We caution that with discussions being early stage, and no guarantee that any value achieved in the transaction would be higher than our risked valuation, and
that there remains no agreement between Acacia and the Government of Tanzania, we maintain our Sector Perform, Speculative Risk rating.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

You'll remember Chinese interest in Acacia previously .....

December69 @Forester, sorry to learn that, the only benefit she'd have had is selling as a retirement/pension from my understanding. But so US based now I rarely keep up with UK Taxes
BE11:56am

https://ftalphavil...n-barrick-endgame/

BE11:56am

My stars, was that really 2012?

LJ another push by Chinese industry into East Africa, fantastic opportunity at asset level if they can get the Tanzanian Govt on side
December69 @BE there's a very good reason for this deal...I haven't read the other article yet so apologies.
Forester @December thanks. No tax to pay on sale thankfully. Mother happily retired at last with the proceeds invested as her pension.
11:57 am
BE11:58am

That was a very, very, very long day of trying to work out what the actual differences were between Chinese controlled gold companies. It's not always entirely clear.

Miss Piggy Wolfgang Münchau getting spiky over new pooled euro-bonds https://www.ft.com/content/b55e37f0-1326-11e8-8cb6-b9ccc4c4dbbb "One gets the sense that the authors’ knowledge of the academic financial market literature exceeds their knowledge of the reality of financial markets. "
December69 China are set for the largest port investment in Tanzania going forward, plus other companies within a JV, essentially ACA are leveraging of with the "Don't mess with my sugar daddy or he won't invest in you!"

December69 Its worth while following the investment @Bagamoyo Port, makes for a very sensible solution to ACA
BE11:59am

In terms of the weekend press, this is interesting.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

https://www.ft.com...-940e-08320fc2a277

BE12:00pm

Mr Weizer hints that further dealmaking is to come, saying “discussions are under way” over a major acquisition without providing further details.

“Deals have a life of their own, it’s not necessarily fully in our control,” he says. “We have a strong balance sheet, and we remain opportunistic and acquisitive.”
